utterances: (As Wall-E) Wall-e.
(As Eve) Wall-e.
(As Wall-E) Aw...
A mess, right?
But even as you hear this in your car or your shower, wherever you are, your brain's responding to every sound in there.
And Kraus and her team could see in the kids' brain waves how well they could separate the speech sound...
Da, da, da, da, da...
From everything else.
(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, ""WALL-E"")
(As Wall-E) Wall-e.
What's the sign of a healthy brain and a strong, future reader?
Brain waves that, in spite of the noise, capture the richness of that tiny, little da, things like timing, harmonics and consistency.
If the brain responds differently to that same sound - the sound hasn't changed - how is the child to learn?
Kraus tested one batch of 3-year-olds, and then tested them again at 4 and was able to predict language skill.
Her team also tested kids as old as 14 and were able to predict reading skill as well as flag learning disabilities.
I asked Kraus what she'd like to see in her looking glass.
My vision for this is to have every child tested at birth.
Because, Kraus says, this science fiction idea is based on something we've known for decades.
When it comes to helping kids with literacy challenges, earlier is better.
Cory Turner, NPR News, Washington.
Now we are going to a Syrian town where just a couple of weeks ago, U.S.
military advisers and airstrikes helped push out ISIS.
That was a relief for the long-suffering people of Shaddadeh.
But another force has taken over and might have its own plans for the town.
NPR's Alice Fordham was in Shaddadeh and sent this report.
There's little things you appreciate when ISIS is kicked out of your town.
On the street outside the town of Shaddadeh, I meet Adnan Sleiman, a tall, thin man with a gray beard, happily smoking.
(Through interpreter) I'm 60 years old, and I feel like I'm 20.
ISIS once put Sleiman in prison for possession of cigarettes.
Now he's selling a tower of packs by the side of the road.
We drive into the town which American-backed forces retook from ISIS about two weeks ago.
It's still pretty empty.
At first, the only sound is the wind on metal shop fronts sprayed with the ISIS logo.
But then, as we pick our way over the debris, we see two women sitting in the sun.
(CROSSTALK)
They're still scared of ISIS, so they won't give their names.
But they tell us that they stayed the whole two years the extremists were here.
They infiltrated gradually.
UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN #1: (Through interpreter) A small cell arrived, just 50 men.
Initially, ISIS worked alongside the moderate rebel forces then controlling the town, but that changed overnight.
UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN #1: (Through interpreter) We went to sleep, and the next day, ISIS were on top of us.
The ISIS fighters killed and arrested the rebel forces and imposed their own brutal rule.
UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN #2: (Through interpreter) They were beheading, executing.
They'd leave the bodies out for five, 10 days.
(CROSSTALK)
Their male relatives pull up plastic chairs to talk to us about the new force in town.
One of them, Asaad Abdullah, says ISIS told them the U.S.-backed fighters known as the Syrian Democratic Forces were criminals.
(Through interpreter) They told us all the possible ways that our women would be violated and our homes would be looted.
But he says they didn't do that, and he's grateful.
U.S.
officials also praised the Syrian Democratic Forces when they took Shaddadeh, a small but strategically located town.
U.S.
special forces even advised during the battle.
But in this little town which keeps changing hands, it's not clear who's going to be in charge next.
(Speaking Kurdish).
As we pass through checkpoints, the soldiers are all speaking Kurdish, not Arabic like the residents.
This is an Arab town, but the Syrian Democratic Forces are dominated by a Kurdish faction which has big political ambitions.
Today, they announced plans to create a federal region here in Northeastern Syria, and that would include Arab areas like Shaddadeh.
Arab leaders say they think Arabs might resist Kurdish control, and the U.S.
says it won't support an autonomous region.
In the nearby town, Kurdish politician Mansour Haj Mansour says his Kurdish-led group can govern this Arab area without kindling ethnic violence, and he hopes this will just be the beginning.
(Through interpreter) We know that it's a big challenge, and all people, all the eyes of outside - they are focusing on this area.
He describes what he calls a brotherhood project where prominent people from the Arab areas will be organized into councils and run their own affairs.
(CROSSTALK)
I would start by extracting it, right?

...And also Tamara reported he's now - sorry, Neil, but just to a moment - he has now won 7 of the last 8 contests - caucuses, the Wisconsin primary, also a global primary of Democrats who live abroad.
How much, though, does this change the delegate math?
This is Neil.
Not a whole hell of a lot.
He's had a nice little run.
But in the big scheme of things he is still far behind in delegates, especially in superdelegates.

When the Sanders campaign talks about neither one of these candidates is going to go to the convention with enough pledged delegates, it completely ignores superdelegates with whom Hillary has a huge lead right now.

So I think, I mean, these last few weeks have been good for Bernie, but it just doesn't change the direction that this Democratic primary is headed in, especially with, you know, New York coming up next week which is a string for Hillary Clinton.
It doesn't change the trajectory of this race which is likely to end with a - with her easily winning the nomination.
So a brokered convention, as his manager suggested, might happen possibly, probably, probably not - yes or no?
It's a pipe dream.
(Laughter) OK, pipe dream - all right.
Stay with us Neil and Margie.
And we're going to talk about how the Republican race shaped up in Wisconsin now with NPR's Sarah McCammon who has been following the GOP candidates.
At a banquet hall in Milwaukee, Texas Sen.

Tonight we once again have hope for the future.
